abstract.para: This role automates the entire lifecycle of TLS or SSL certificates, including both issuance and renewal.

section.title: certificate role variables
section.para: Instead of a single and a standardized set of variables, the role uses several distinct variable groups to handle different aspects of certificate management.

listitem.para: certificate_requests: is the most important variable group. It is a list of dictionaries, where each dictionary defines the details for a single certificate you want to create or manage. This is where you specify the domain, subject alternative names, key size, and other core certificate details. The default is [].

certificate_wait: controls whether an Ansible task should pause and wait for a certificate to be successfully issued by a Certificate Authority (CA) before proceeding. The default value is true, which means that that subsequent tasks in your playbook like configuring a web server does not run until the certificate is available, preventing errors caused by missing files.

example.title: A certificate playbook example
example.para: This playbook assumes a certificate and private key already exist on the target machine and are located in a standard directory. It sets the file owner to root and the group to a specific user nginx, to allow the web server to read the certificate while keeping the private key secure.
example.screen:
- name: Set certificate owner and group hosts: webservers # Target your web servers become: true # Required to change file ownership
vars: certificate_path: /etc/pki/tls/certs/mycert.crt private_key_path: /etc/pki/tls/private/mycert.key webserver_user: nginx
tasks: - name: Set owner and group for the private key ansible.builtin.file: path: "{{ private_key_path }}" owner: root group: "{{ webserver_user }}" mode: '0640'
- name: Set owner and group for the certificate ansible.builtin.file: path: "{{ certificate_path }}" owner: root group: "{{ webserver_user }}" mode: '0644'
